Please read a giant agenda item 1 into the Recordan ordinance related to city finances; creating a fund for depositing donations, gifts, and grants related to the city of Seattle's response to the Covid- 19 pandemic; creating a budget summary level; amending ordinance 126000, which adopted the 2020 budget; changing appropriations to various departments and budget control levels, and from various funds in the budget; declaring an emergency; and establishing an immediate effective date; all by a 3/4 vote of the city council.
This is a bill that I am sponsoring.

In response to this Covid-19 outbreak and its economic effects many are feeling philanthropic.

Business partners have expressed interest in donating resources in Seattle that maybe a need . article 1 section 1 of the city charter provides that the city of Seattle may accept gifts and donations of all kinds to carry out the purposes of the gifts and donations.

However our city municipal code requires that even though and a proclaimed civil emergency he may or may accept gifts or grants, the council must act Legislatively to allow for the acceptance of those gifts, grants or loans.
That is what this is about.
The legislation will create a new fund in the city Treasury for the receipt of gifts, donations and grants and to the management and recovery of crisis created by the Covid-19 global pandemic.

The uses of these funds could include food assistance, financial assistance, assistance with Childcare, loan guarantees, rent assistance and operating assistance to cultural and nonprofit organizations.
We will be considering some amendments this afternoon to expand that list of allowable uses.
I considered that to be friendly and minutes.
This would also create a new budget summary level line to allow city departments to spend from the new fund for the purpose of assisting in the recovery of the Covid-19 pandemic.

It also gives the executive authority to accept gifts, donations and grants consistent with the purchases of the bond without additional approval by the city council so as to move it forward in a timely manner.

There also be an amendment that we will consider this afternoon that requires reporting back to the city council so we can make sure the executive is still thing accountable to the intent and design of this legislation.
This would also give a preparation to finance general contingent on the receipt of those donations, so they can quickly deploy resources.
Last legislation is necessary to be considered emergency legislation to go into immediate effect in order to protect public health safety and welfare.
That is a summary of the legislation and what it is intended to address.

As a counselor it is important that we understand the full picture of dollars going to support various needs such as small business support copied assistant, homeless support and housing so we are able to make informed decisions about other expenditures.

The amendment that is included here in amendment one would require weekly reporting on how these funds are being spent so we are able to maintain proper oversight and enabling expedient direction of these funds to where they need to go in the community as fast as possible.

An ordinance amending ordinance 126000, which adopted the 2020 budget; changing appropriations to the executive Department's office of Sustainability and environment, the Department of neighborhoods, the Department of education and early learning, Seattle parks and recreation, and budget control levels, and from various funds in the budget, for the purpose of providing food support to individuals in Seattle; and ratifying and confirming certain prior acts; all by a 3/4 vote of the city council.

I want to think the Mayor's office for sending down this legislation to transfer $5 million from the budget resources to a new food voucher program which will provide grocery money for many families in need.
Thousands of families across Seattle.
The Council bill 119764 creates this fund in an effort with the office of Sustainability to support 6000 families facing foods insecurity because of the response of covered.
It is funded with the sugary sweet beverage tax revenue.
Due to the crisis we are in we decided to Reallocate some of the funds that will go to parks in the Department of neighborhoods to make sure we could provide food security for these families.

The community advisory board of the tax revenue provides ongoing analysis and feedback to this Council on the implementation of the tax, we have contacted them and as you all saw the other corresponds back to the counselor there was a few questions.
They were supportive of the reallocation of the funds.
Due to the large layoffs, we need to make sure we are maintaining food security for families across the city to put food on their table.
The Council is a governing body and we have to make tough decisions and I think this is one of them on how we spend our resources in response to Covid- 19.

These are important programs and many of you spent years trying to get this effort off the ground and passed and in limited, the city must push pause in order to ensure families in Seattle especially the kids have food that they need so they can remain healthy during this public health crisis.
I want to thank all of you on your past work on the sugary and sweet bill effort.

I move to adopt resolution 31939

Councilmember Herbold you are the.

As I mentioned at the briefing this is a resolution for the Seattle bid to host the 2025 National League of cities conference, the National League of cities in the country's oldest and largest organization serving municipal governments with a mission to strengthen and promote cities at centers of opportunity, leadership and Governance.
Seattle is a long-term, longtime member and previously hosted this conference in 2013.
Visit Seattle is preparing Seattle's bid working in partnership with the Association of Washington cities.

The Mayor has signed a letter indicating her support for hosting the 2025 conference, my office has previously circulated additional information to all Council members about this conference and its expected impact on Seattle.
Including answers to a checklist of questions that is required by resolution 3034 for special events.
This resolution declares the city council support of the bid and invites the National League of cities to conduct a site visit here as a considers were to host.
It is projected to be about 4500 attendees with an estimated impact of $13.8 million for the city of Seattle.
Some industries are being Hard- hit by the Coronavirus right now.

2018 some of you may remember Councilmember back Shaw sponsored and the past in support of hosting the conference . The checklist of questions required resolution 3034 when considering hosting events was not prepared.
Visit Seattle believes a new resolution that specifically identifies 2025 is the target date will be required to ensure a competitive bid.
Given the desire for a new resolution, I initiated the review process outlined in resolution 303402 ensure the city council is providing appropriate oversight for large events.

Central staff reviewed and visited the request and indicated that the conference meets the definition of a major event in the resolution because City resources will be required for planning and or security.
Special permitting is unlikely to be required.

This is unlikely to result in the triggering of a future obligation as anticipated as he resolution anticipates concerns with future obligations and the city's financial exposure and resource commitment to the event is unlikely to meet the threshold to trigger that obligation.
In addition, another trigger is anticipated over time expenditures exceeding 3% of the police Department's budget for overtime.
Another trigger that is not anticipated to be met.
I requested that the office complete an evaluation of the request using the checklist of questions from resolution 30430.
That's all I have.

First I want to apologize to my colleagues.
I left everything this morning to go to the field hospital before actually having the opportunity to share with you this information about the resolution.
I will do that now.
Before I do that I want to acknowledge and think Councilmember Sawant.
She is circulating a letter and petition to achieve a similar goal.
Councilmember Mosqueda is also circulating a letter, I think all of us as a cancel are eager to make sure we are protecting our neighbors.
This resolution is really aimed at protecting, I'm sure all of your getting calls from your constituents about their fear, the rent prices . It is the end of the month.
We have constituents worried about making rent payments.
We also have landlords that their tenants cannot pay rent but who still have mortgage payments that they are responsible for.
This is really calling on the governor to use his emergency power to freeze rent and calling our Federal legislators to freeze mortgage payments during this public health crisis.
I am getting hundreds of Emails from folks for those worried about covering their bills.
The truth is we have tens of thousands of Seattleites who are worried we may be entering a recession and possibly worse.
We want to make sure we are do something now to protect people from not being able to cover this debt later.
We are proposing this resolution, I want to let folks know that we are working with other legislators on the West Coast.

This is part of of a broad coalition of supervisors from San Francisco, Council members from Los Angeles, Boston, New York State Senator, who are moving these kinds of resolutions through their jurisdictions in the next week in a real effort to push our Federal administrators to make this happen and to keep people in their homes during this crisis where they are safest.
So I move passage of this resolution.

This question is for the sponsor, Councilmember Morales.

Regarding the moratorium on residential and commercial rent payments, I want to clarify its intent would be that we are asking the governor and Federal legislators to temporarily suspend the payments but at the end of the crisis the payments will be due or are we asking for them to all right forgive all payments and they will never be due?
We are asking for them to be forgiven.

I am getting hundreds of calls a day and Emails from people saying that if I don't pay rent for four months, especially in Seattle where rent is $2000, there is no way the accumulated debt is anything I will ever be able to pay off.
Summarily for property owners.
This is a crisis that people are expressing across the country.

We are saying in the situation we need to just freeze the rent for folks until the crisis is over, that might be two months or three months, that should not be added on to the end of the rent payments especially if folks might be ending their lease, it just creates for application.
We are calling for a rent freeze for the time that the crisis is lifted and people are able to go back to work and pay their bills.
Whether they are Renters or have a mortgage payment.

I again want to thank our central staff.

I know that they did a--also on Friday I circulated to your offices a Sign-On letter for the city of Seattle, the Council members, to send a message to our governor's office to extend a moratorium on all foreclosures including multifamily structures and commercial properties throughout the state.

This is in line with much of the conversation we have already had today so I will just say that while there has been action taken at the city in the state to protect--from Eviction all of our offices are carrying the concerns that we already talked about today that banks will Foreclose on thousands of property owners and that those property owners are facing a loss of income for households and small businesses due to the downward spiral in the market.

A lot of our Renters who live in the city live in multifamily structures and families across Washington are being forced to choose between necessities like food or paying for rent while many businesses are also struggling to stay afloat, and may be unable to make their rent or mortgage payment as a result of this crisis.
Placing a moratorium on Evictions will complement other protections we have already enacted at the city of Seattle and that we have seen echoed at the state level thanks to governor Inslee.

I think this would support housing stability and economic resilience and would help us--a statewide moratorium on and on foreclosures would--to implement a foreclosure and Eviction moratorium for Single- family homeowners with FHA insured mortgages for the next few days.

It also response to the call from the local housing alliance to enact foreclosure moratoriums . The letter has been discussed with the governor's office and the governor's staff and I think that they appreciate us continuing to elevate these issues they said that a letter would be welcomed as they look at varying strategies at the state level to address and request that they are also getting.

So with your consideration we would love to have Councilmembers sign onto the letter that has been circulated, we will affix your electronic signature to the letter if you indicate that you are interested in signing on.

Thanks to Councilmember Herbold for weighing in as well and you have already heard other Councilmembers who are working on similar efforts, I really appreciate your consideration of signing onto this letter to the governor's office to continue to amplify the call for statewide action I appreciate all that has happened in our effort already to try to protect homeowners and small business owners.

This would be a really important measure as we look at protecting Renters and those who are paying as small business owners as well, so thanks for the consideration, and thanks to Councilmember Pedersen for drafting the original letter.
